facts.text: Petitioner is a partnership firm which manufactures and sells bidis under the name Anwarkhan Mehboob and Co., Jabalpur.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner is a partnership firm which manufactures and sells, bidis, under the name and style of Anwarkhan Mehboob and Co., Jabalpur.

facts.text: Petitioner firm acquired right to pluck and carry away tendu leaves from plants in ninety-nine villages in the former Imlai Estate from Malguzar Raja Raghuraj Singh for 25 years from 1948 to 1973.

anchor.surface_text: In 1948 the petitioner firm, with a view to securing a supply of tendu leaves over the years acquired for a term of 25 years, the right to pluck and carry away tendu leaves from plants in ninety-nine villages in the former Imlai Estate from the Malguzar Raja Raghuraj Singh.

facts.text: Document annexure I executed by Raja Raghuraj Singh on August 22, 1948, selling tendu leaves in 99 villages for 25 years for Rs. 9,000 per year.

anchor.surface_text: The period of 25 years was to run from 1948 to 1973. The document, which was number registered  annexure I , was executed by the Raja on August 22, 1948. It is a very brief document and all that it says is that tendu leaves in 99 villages have been sold for 25 years for a companysideration of Rs. 9,000 per year which must be paid after each tendu leaf crop is over but before the expiry of three months, that only the leaves should be plucked and that numberbushes should be cut down.

facts.text: Madhya Pradesh Abolition of Proprietary Rights Estates, Mahals and Alienated Lands Act No. 1 of 1951 passed in 1950.

anchor.surface_text: In 1950 the Madhya Pradesh Abolition of Proprietary Rights  Estates, Mahals and Alienated Lands  Act  No. 1 of 1951  was passed. Under the Act  ,which may be briefly called the Abolition Act  all rights,. title and interest vesting in the proprietor or any person having interest in such proprietary right through the pro- prietor, in an area to which the Abolition Act was extended including land  cultivable or barren , grass land, scrub- jungle forest, trees etc., ceased and vested in the State for purposes of State, free from all encumbrances.

facts.text: Government of Madhya Pradesh obstructed persons holding contracts for tendu leaves including petitioner firm.

anchor.surface_text: The Government of Madhya Pradesh obstructed the persons who held companytracts for tendu leaves Jac, wood, timber or other forest produce, including the petitioner firm,

facts.text: Petitioner firm filed Writ Petition No. 309 of 1951 under Art. 32, heard with dozen others, decided on December 23, 1952.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner firm and many others petitioned to this Court under Art. 32 of the Constitution to enforce what they des- cribed as fundamental rights to property, and asked for writs or orders to restrain the State Government from enforcing the Abolition Act generally and in particular so as to interfere with the right of the petitioner firm to pick, gather and carry away the kind of forest produce for which they held agreements. A dozen such petitions were heard together, that of the petitioner being W. P. No. 309 of 1951  Firm Anwar Khan Mehboob Co. v. State of Madhya Pradesh , and were decided on December 23, 1952.

facts.text: Supreme Court in Chhotabhai Jethabhai case held contracts like petitioner's were licenses not affected by Abolition Act, issued writ of prohibition.

anchor.surface_text: The main judgment of this Court was pronounced in a petition filed by one Chhotabhai Jethabhai and is reported in Chhotabhai Jethabhai v. State of Madhya Pradesh 1 . A Divisional Bench of this Court held that companytracts and agreements, such as the one held by the petitioner firm, were in essence and effect licenses granted to the transferees to cut, gather and carry away, the produce in the shape of tends leaves, lac, or timber or wood. Holding further that there was numberhing in the Abolition Act to affect their validity or to extinguish such rights in favour of the State, the Divisional Bench ruled that the State had numberright to interfere with the rights under the companytracts and agreements. A writ of prohibition was issued, prohibiting the State from interfering in any manner whatsoever with the enjoyment of those rights.

facts.text: Petitioner firm obtained writ of prohibition in 1952 case.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner firm, in companymon with the other petitioners, on that occasion obtained a writ of prohibition also. It would have enjoyed the fruits of its agreement with the Raja till the year 1973 but other events followed.

facts.text: Madhya Pradesh Tendu Patta Vyapar Viniyaman Adhiniyam, 1964 (No. 29 of 1964) passed in 1964 to regulate trade in tendu leaves by creating State monopoly.

anchor.surface_text: In 1964 the Madhya Pradesh Tendu Patta  Vyapar Viniyaman  Adhiniyam, 1964  29 of 1964 ,  companyveniently called the Adhiniyam  was passed, as the preamble openly professes to make provision for regulating in the public interest the trade of Tendu leaves by creation of State  1  1953 S. C. R. 476 monopoly in such trade.

facts.text: Adhiniyam divides areas into units, appoints agents, sets prices, requires registration, imposes restrictions on purchase and transport under s.5.

anchor.surface_text: The Adhiniyam companyferred power on the State Government to divide specified arm into units, to appoint its own agents for purchase and trade in tendu leaves, to set up advisory companymittees especially for the fixation of prices at which Government would purchase tendu leaves from growers of tendu leaves other than Government, to open depots and to purchase there tendu leaves at prices in the lists exhibited there. The Adhiniyam also required growers of tendu leaves, the manufacturers of bidis and exporters of tendu leaves to register. With a view to creating monopoly in favour of Government section 5 of the Adhiniyam imposed a companyplete restriction on purchase and transport of tendu leaves companytrary to the provisions of the Adhiniyam and companytravention of any provision was made punishable with imprisonment or fine and power was also given to forfeit the whole or any part of tendu leaves in respect of which there was companytravention.

facts.text: Imlai Estate divided into unit No. 3 Baghraji leased area, unit No. 5 Kundam leased area, and unit No. 11 Umaria leased area.

anchor.surface_text: By numberification the State of Madhya Pradesh, declared the areas to which the Adhiniyam extended and subdivided the area into units. The Imlai Estate, in respect of which the petitioner firm held its agreement, was divided up into unit No. 3 Baghraji leased area, unit No. 5 Kundam leased area, and unit No. 11 Umaria leased area.

facts.text: State Government invited tenders for areas including the three units, noting they were leased to petitioner firm up to 1973. No tenders for units 5 and 11, one for unit 3.

anchor.surface_text: The State Government then invited tenders for the areas including the three units but the remarks companyumn showed that these units were leased by the Malguzar to the petitioner firm up to the year 1973. No tenders were received for units 5 and 1 1 but there was a tender for unit 3.

facts.text: On March 20, 1965, Minister for Forests informed petitioner firm's representatives that their leases stood extinguished by Adhiniyam and extended time for fresh tenders.

anchor.surface_text: On March 20, 1965 the Minister for Forests in a meeting, informed the representatives of the petitioner firm that their leases stood extinguished by reason of the Adhiniyam and that time was extended for submission of fresh tenders in respect of the units left out.

facts.text: On March 23, 1965, tenders for unit 3 Baghraji and unit 11 Umaria accepted.

anchor.surface_text: On March 23, 1965 tenders made by two persons in respect of unit 3  Baghraji  and unit 11  Umaria  were accepted

facts.text: On March 24, 1965, Divisional Forest Officer informed petitioner firm by letter that right to collect tendu leaves in 99 villages abrogated under Adhiniyam.

anchor.surface_text: and the Next day the petitioner firm was informed, by letter from the Divisional Forest Officer, Jabalpur Division, that the right to companylect tendu leaves in all the 99 villages of Imlai Estate was abrogated by the State Government under the Adhiniyam. The present petition was then filed.

facts.text: Present case is Writ Petition No. 38 of 1965 under Art. 32 in original jurisdiction.

anchor.surface_text: ORIGINAL JURISDICTION Writ Petition No. 38 of 1965. Petition under Art. 32 of the Constitution of India for the enforcement of fundamental rights.

facts.text: It was admitted that petitioner firm is not a grower of tendu leaves as defined.

anchor.surface_text: Each of the terms holder of a service land, Government lessee, tenant and tenure holder is separately defined but as it was admitted before us that the petitioner firm is number one of them, the definitions need number detain us.

facts.text: Court holds that earlier 1952 decision does not operate as res judicata.

anchor.surface_text: We may begin by companysidering the companyrectness of the companytention that the earlier decision operates as res judicata in this case.

anchor.surface_text: That ruling must be held number binding., Mr. Pathak, however, companytended that whatever might be the position vis-a-vis other cases, since the decision was given in respect of the agreement in favour of the petitioner firm, it must companytrol subsequent cases by the rule of res judicata.

facts.text: Petitioner's rights under 1948 agreement are licenses coupled with grant, not property rights before plucking.

anchor.surface_text: Jr The petitioner firm like the others had a licence to go to the forests to pick and carry away tendu leaves but had numberother right.

facts.text: Adhiniyam s.5 restricts purchase/transport to State Govt, officers, agents; deems petitioner's collection as contravention.

anchor.surface_text: The operative provision is to be found in the first sub-section which says that after a numberification is issued under sub-s.  3  of s. 1  which extends the Adhiniyam to any area  numberperson shall purchase or transport tendu leaves except the State Government or officer authorised in writing in this behalf or an agent of that Government in respect of any unit in which the leaves are grown.

facts.text: Court holds petition fails as petitioner has no property right invaded by Adhiniyam.

anchor.surface_text: The petition must, therefore, fail.

issues.text: Does the earlier decision operate as res judicata in this case?

anchor.surface_text: We may begin by considering the correctness of the contention that the earlier decision operates as res judicata in this case.

issues.text: Does the Adhiniyam touch the rights of the petitioner firm as recognized and enforced by the earlier writ of prohibition, or nullify the decision expressly or indirectly?

anchor.surface_text: The arguments of Mr. G. S. Pathak in support of the petition were really two although they covered a good deal of ground. His first contention was that the Adhiniyam did not touch the rights of the petitioner firm as recognized and enforced by this Court by its writ of prohibition in the earlier case and that the Adhiniyam had not attempted to nullify the decision of this Court either expressly or even indirectly by making the law retrospective.

issues.text: Does the Adhiniyam in terms apply to the petitioner firm or is it excluded by Explanation I to section 5?

anchor.surface_text: His next contention was that the Adhiniyam in terms did not apply to the petitioner firm because of Explanation 1 to s. 5 of the Adhiniyam. He claimed that the petitioner firm was entitled to move this Court for the enforcement of the same fundamental right in property which had been recognized by this Court on the earlier occasion and the former decision was binding in this case as res judicata.

issues.text: What is the effect of the Adhiniyam upon the rights of the petitioner firm under the agreement obtained from the Raja?

anchor.surface_text: The core of the problem thus is what is the effect of the Adhiniyam upon the rights of the petitioner firm under the agreement it had obtained from Raja? For this purpose, we have to go to the terms of s. 5 of the Adhiniyam already set out. The operative provision is to be found in the first sub-section which says that after a notification is issued under sub-s. (3) of s. 1

issues.text: Is there a fundamental right to property of the petitioner firm infringed by section 5 of the Adhiniyam so as to maintain the petition under Article 32?

anchor.surface_text: On behalf of the State the learned Attorney-General contended that there was no right in property which could be claimed and -the petition was incompetent in view of the later decisions of this Court which had dissented from Chhotabhai Jethabhai's case and that, in any event, the matter then decided could not have taken notice of the Adhiniyam which was not in existence.

anchor.surface_text: The second Explanation says that a person having no interest in a holding but who has acquired the right to collect tendu leaves grown on such holding shall be deemed to have purchased such leaves in contravention of the Adhiniyam.

holdings.text: The earlier decision does not operate as res judicata because the cause of action is different.

anchor.surface_text: For this reason we do not think that-the earlier decision operates as res judicata, even if it might have been assumed in that case that a right to property was involved.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Different statutes (Abolition Act vs Adhiniyam) create distinct causes of action; Hoystead distinguished as inapplicable to new law.

holdings.text: Chhotabhai Jethabhai case is not binding as it was given per incuriam.

anchor.surface_text: It was, therefore, laid down that the decision in Chhotabhai Jethabhai's case 1 , which treated the agreements as bare licences and yet considered that a fundamental right to property was conferred by them, was apparently given per incuriam

holdings.reasoning_summary: Failed to notice no fundamental right in bare licenses; dissented in Shantabai and Mahadeo.

holdings.text: The petitioner's agreement is a licence coupled with a grant conferring no property right before severance.

anchor.surface_text: Jr The petitioner firm like the others had a licence to go to the forests to pick and carry away tendu leaves but had no other right.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applies doctrine of licence coupled with grant; right ends with licensor's title vesting in State.

holdings.text: Section 5 of the Adhiniyam applies to the petitioner firm as to any other person.

anchor.surface_text: The core of the problem thus is what is the effect of the Adhiniyam upon the rights of the petitioner firm under the agreement it had obtained from Raja? For this purpose, we have to go to the terms of s. 5 of the Adhiniyam already set out.

holdings.reasoning_summary: 'No person' includes petitioner; earlier writ only against Abolition Act, not new Adhiniyam.

holdings.text: Explanation II to s.5 deems a person like petitioner who acquired right to collect as having purchased in contravention.

anchor.surface_text: The second Explanation says that a person having no interest in a holding but who has acquired the right to collect tendu leaves grown on such holding shall be deemed to have purchased such leaves in contravention of the Adhiniyam.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Petitioner has no interest in holding; prior agreement deemed contravention.

holdings.text: No fundamental right to property is invaded by the Adhiniyam as no property right exists before plucking.

anchor.surface_text: Since there is no right to property before the leaves are plucked, no such rights can be said to be invaded by the Adhiniyam.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Licence/contract not property; follows Shantabai, Mahadeo; no severance yet.

holdings.text: The petition fails as no fundamental right under Art. 32 is violated.

Precedent on agreement classifications including bare licenses addresses issue on effect of Adhiniyam on such agreements.
p5 no interest beyond crops obtained supports h3 no property right before severance
